comments.body: Do you think it's clear enough to the user that that this isn't supported in Scala 3 files? For example I triggered this in a Scala 3 file: And while we are logging this here that the rule isn't supported in this target version, do you think it might make sense to actually show this warning to the user to make it explicit why they are seeing the above message about the code action not being found?

I think it's a bit different, since we are not adding the action at all and Metals is not expected to work in this case. Also, if someone has organize imports on save it would continuously show the message, because it will never work.

We can update it if it will be confusing for users.

          scribe.info(
            s"Organize import doesn't work on ${target.scalaVersion} files"

          Future.successful(Seq())

comments.body: I think it should be a command here, otherwise organize imports is invoked every time we move a cursor :O
ok! I didn't know what's the difference between command and edit

Command just specifies what should be run if the action is selected, while edit already defines what should be done. 

The problem with recalculating code actions on cursor move is something that is really hidden. We should use command if possible.
